body.title: Could AI spell an early death for VR cameras? New iPhone app tries to do just that
body.description: A new app could make high-resolution virtual reality footage possible with just an iPhone or iPad. Announced on November 25, ...
body.article_content:
When you buy through links on our articles, Future and its syndication partners may earn a commission.

The Teleport by Varjo app uses AI and an iPhone to create 3D locations. | Credit: Varjo

A new app could make high-resolution virtual reality footage possible with just an iPhone or iPad. Announced on November 25, Teleport by Varjo is a mobile app that uses AI to construct high-resolution 3D scans without specialized equipment. The company claims the app is the first to allow the VR scanning with just a smartphone.

The Teleport app uses generative AI built with NVIDIA GPUs to create virtual reality content from a smartphone. In an interview with Digital Camera World, the company explained that the app uses AI to create a representation from a series of images. The app doesn’t require LiDAR, but iPhones with the technology can use it for enhanced results, Varjo noted.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement

The app walks users through scanning a location, creating 3D scenes that can then be viewed on a computer, smartphone, or with a virtual reality headset. At launch, the app is available for iPhone and iPad and requires iOS 17 or later.

Unlike Apple’s spatial video, the Teleport photos shared by Varjo allow viewers to move within the space, looking between objects and taking in the room from different viewing angles. Spatial video, on the other hand, captures some depth but leaves the viewer “standing” in the same spot.

According to Varjo, scanning a scene in 3D took around five to ten minutes in beta testing. The company says that 2,000 professionals helped test the beta version of the Teleport app, creating a library of online Teleport scans. The app both reduces the time and complexity involved with full 3D captures, Varjo says, with commercial uses like construction, inspection or training as well as personal applications like saving a view of your wedding venue to relive in VR later.

The scans also allow for measuring the space from the 3D scans, including a rescaling tool for more accurate measurements. The company notes the measuring option isn’t designed for high-precision engineering, but can prove helpful for applications like design.

Advertisement Advertisement

While the app aims to create a lower entry into the field of VR and 3D scans, the Teleport app requires a subscription that starts at $30 / €24 / AU$ 46. Still, the cost is significantly lower than the price of pro-grade 3D VR cameras, or the cost of Canon’s unique dual optics for the R mount. The app, however, is designed for scanning places, where VR cameras can also capture 3D video.

While pro-grade VR 3D equipment isn’t new, the growth of the technology has arguably been slow, as the VR headsets that deliver the most full experience are far from as widespread as smartphones and laptops. The high cost of the cameras required for such scans also likely played a role, which means a lower entry point like the Telephoto app could potentially spark some growth.

Not a fan of AI? Find the best 360 cameras, or browse our favorite photography apps. Also check out our guide to the best cameras for real estate photography

body.title: Locals Believe a Pub in the English Countryside Is Haunted. We Tagged Along With Ghost Hunters to Uncover the Truth.
body.description: A ghost in scorched rags. Mysterious whispers. Appliances switching on by themselves. Strange sightings at the Sparkford Inn ...
body.article_content:
Flickers of light dance within the fireplace of the Sparkford Inn’s dining room, the warmth overshadowed by rumors of ghosts lingering in the shadows. A team of paranormal investigators arrive one misty March evening to search for a giggling boy whom many guests have reportedly seen darting around the bar, across the dining room, and playing in the pool room. Witnesses have described him as about seven years old, dressed in scorched rags, and bearing burn marks—features that suggest he is no ordinary child. He is, they claim, a ghost.

Caroline McKendrick, lead investigator at Somerset Paranormal Investigators UK (SPI UK), a group that has been probing paranormal phenomena since 2012, says that reports of the boy often coincide with unexplained events. “Several objects were mysteriously knocked off the kitchen counter, and the dishwasher switched on by itself, even when no one was nearby,” McKendrick says. For years, staff and guests alike have reported strange occurrences: whispers in empty rooms, objects moving on their own, and other ghostly figures, including a domineering man and a woman who frequents Room No. 6.

These accounts, along with a local urban legend about the Inn’s haunted past, convinced the six members of SPI UK to investigate. Tucked away in the small village of Somerset in southwest England, the Sparkford Inn dates back to the late Middle Ages. Over the centuries, it has served as a stopover for horse-drawn coaches, a popular lodging place for visitors, and a meeting point for local hunters. Today, it’s a cozy hotel and pub. McKendrick and company arrived here with the goal of not only cataloging these apparitions, but proving they’re full-bodied spirits, which are interactive entities that can produce physical effects and respond to human contact.

For the investigators, the stakes are high. The popularity of shows like Ghost Hunters and Paranormal Witness have fueled a fascination with the supernatural. But for SPI UK, it’s more than a trend, it’s a pursuit for real answers. Tracking down the elusive ghosts at the Sparkford Inn will put their skills and equipment to the test. Capturing tangible evidence of the paranormal would be a major breakthrough, advancing ghost hunting as a legitimate field of study—far beyond mere entertainment or pseudoscience.

Following McKendrick through the Inn’s dimly lit corridors, the investigators are carrying large cases of technical equipment. Their toolkit includes electromagnetic field meters (EFMs) and thermal imaging cameras. While none of the team members are formally trained scientists, they bring many years of hands-on experience to their investigations, approaching cases with what they consider to be scientific rigor. Paranormal investigations, they say, follow a structured process that includes on-site visits, interviews with witnesses, and data collection. Afterward, the team analyzes the data for patterns and anomalies, like reviewing audio recordings for electronic voice phenomena.

Alamy

To investigate the boy spirit, the team relies on their tried-and-tested methods, tuning their approach to encourage communication. They’ve brought a teddy bear, play balls, and a toy clock to lure the young boy ghost into contact.

“You communicate with the child’s spirit the way you would with living children,” says Donna Lalla, a paranormal investigator on the SPI UK team. Lalla is cordial and soft-spoken with short silver-gray hair and glasses. She tries to bring a nurturing energy to the team, especially for investigations involving children. “You encourage play, you start a nursery rhyme. You start singing “Ring-Around-the Rosie” and wait for the young ghost to pick up the rhyme,” Lalla continues. She begins to hum the tune, hoping the young ghost joins in.

Everyone waits.

● ● ●

Despite their best efforts, the team has yet to find convincing proof of a ghost. They partly blame their equipment, which is powerful, but not exactly designed for paranormal investigations. Electromagnetic Field detectors (EMFs), for example, detect electrical-wiring issues in the workplace or at home, and thermal-imaging cameras identify heat signatures in construction and firefighting. Still, the investigators persist, optimizing the tools they have, hungry for a breakthrough.

The idea of a realm between life and death—where spirits linger and interact with the living—has fascinated humankind across cultures and centuries. This belief in ghosts, spirits, and the supernatural has deep roots in ancient cultures, with references found in Egyptian tomb texts, Greek epics like The Odyssey, and early Chinese ghost stories.

In 1882, paranormal investigations took on more scientific undertones when a group of scholars and intellectuals, from physicists to journalists, founded The Society for Psychical Research (SPR) in London, the first organization dedicated to the scientific study of paranormal and supernatural phenomena. The SPR aimed to apply scientific methods and principles to the study of paranormal and supernatural phenomena, covering telepathy, mediumship, and apparitions.

Then the American Society for Psychical Research emerged in 1884 when physicist Sir William Barrett persuaded authoritative scientific figures and intellectuals—such as the Scottish-born American inventor of the telephone, Alexander Graham Bell, and William James, the father of American psychology—that it was vital to apply the scientific method to psychical phenomena. James himself dove headfirst into investigating mediums, attending séances. His aim was twofold and conflicting by today’s standards: to understand the depths of human consciousness and to explore the possibility that consciousness might transcend the physical body, potentially explaining life after death itself.

As these groups evolved, so did the tools they employed. Early ghost hunters relied primarily on observational methods and interviews . They would conduct séances, monitor mediums, and document irregular phenomena in detail—for example table movements or unexplained sounds during séances. As technology advanced, investigators began incorporating new instruments and adapting them to suit their needs.

“Spirits need tremendous amounts of energy to penetrate the sphere of the living,” explains Lalla, adjusting an EMF meter as the team prepares for the night’s investigation. Today, at the Sparkford Inn, the SPI UK team brings a range of these tools into the field. They hope their handheld EMF devices will detect spikes in electromagnetic energy, which they believe might signal the presence of spirits.

Stav Dimitropoulos

A few moments later in the dimly lit corridor, Lalla scans the room with a thermal imaging camera, looking for heat signatures that might suggest an unaccounted presence. Nearby, another team member positions motion sensors near an antique rocking chair that, according to reports, has mysteriously moved in the past. The faint buzz of a Geiger counter fills the air, its needle steady but poised to detect any spikes in radiation—a phenomenon some link to psychic activity.

Digital voice recorders capture potential paranormal voices, while body cams ensure every moment is documented. One investigator monitors an environmental device, noting fluctuations in barometric pressure and humidity. “If a spirit manifests, it could subtly alter the immediate environment,” she explains, pointing to the screen.

But these tools are only as effective as the investigators who wield them.

● ● ●

The feeble light from the hallway barely reaches the edges of Room No. 6 as the SPI UK team gathers around their equipment, their whispers blending with the creaks of the old floorboards. “Ask her something specific,” McKendrick says to Lalla, who is adjusting the settings on something called a spirit box. The device rapidly scans through radio frequencies, generating white noise that ghost hunters believe spirits can manipulate and communicate through. The spirit box crackles to life, its static filling the room as the investigators lean closer, straining to hear. Suddenly, a faint, almost imperceptible whisper cuts through the noise. The sound is fleeting, but it’s enough to send a ripple of energy through the team.

“Did you hear that?” McKendrick asks, her voice a mixture of agony and elation. The team exchanges wide-eyed glances, the room suddenly electric with possibility.

For a moment, no one moves, ears straining for any follow-up. Lalla tilts her head toward the spirit box, her expression intent. “Was that her?” McKendrick finally murmurs. “The woman from Room No. 6?”

Getty Images

The team replays the recording, each straining to interpret the faint response. Could it have been a “yes” or a soft hum of agreement? The ambiguity only deepens the mystery.

Later, McKendrick reflects on the moment with tempered excitement. “We caught a couple of incomprehensible voices in response to questions during callouts,” she admits. “But they were more like uh huhs and mmms. If it had been clearer, I would have had the sound enhanced with an audio expert.”

What exactly did the team hear? Was it an eerie whisper from beyond or something more prosaic? The equipment ghostbusters rely on—tools like spirit boxes and EMFs—can pick up far more than just spirits. Static interference, stray radio signals, or even the voices of nearby people can all masquerade as spectral activity.

Skeptics like Christopher French, a British psychologist and head of the Anomalistic Psychology Research Unit in the Psychology Department at Goldsmiths, University of London, argue that such tools often mislead investigators. “To check whether allegedly paranormal phenomena are occurring, it’s crucial to consider all possible explanations,” French says. He suggests that whispers like those heard at the Sparkford Inn might simply be quiet noises from living people nearby, misinterpreted as ghostly communication, or random background noise amplified by eager imaginations.

French also highlights a broader issue: the lack of rigorous data collection across time, which he argues is essential for true investigations of the unknown. Without such scientific scrutiny, the accuracy of instruments in paranormal use cases remain dubious.

“These people want to give the appearance that they are doing science, but they really aren’t,” French says. “To check whether allegedly haunted locations have unusual patterns of electromagnetic activity, for example, you need to collect vast amounts of data in three dimensions across time. Without such scientific appraisal, the accuracy of instruments in paranormal use cases remains highly questionable. “Those phantom outlines appearing on your thermal camera are usually specks of dust,” French says.

In the case of the voice on the team’s spirit box, French also has a theory. “Most probably they inadvertently recorded living people speaking to each other that they didn't realize were in the area. Or sometimes even random background noises,” he says.

Getty Images

Lalla, however, disagrees. “I just sit in a dark room, waiting,” she says, estimating that up to two-thirds of her investigations produce no evidence at all. But her team never forces results. Take the scene with the toys, for instance. The teddy bear remained untouched. The toy clock never ticked, and no giggle or playful knock ever broke the silence. The lull of waiting is both part of the challenge and the mystery of their work. Lalla hums a nursery rhyme, but the room stays eerily still—a subtle reminder that the paranormal often chooses its own time to speak, if at all.

French acknowledges that while some teams are sincere in their mission, others may embellish evidence for sensational results. For many, French adds, the appeal lies in the social aspect and the status of being a paranormal investigator just as much as the search for real evidence. Still, the allure of the unexplained keeps investigators returning to allegedly spirit-infested places, where the line between ordinary and extraordinary occasionally blurs.

About six months after their March investigation, McKendrick and her husband, who is also on the SPI UK team, visited the Sparkford Inn once again and met the new assistant manager. She shared a peculiar incident from early September that left her quite distressed. She was near the pool table when, suddenly, a pool ball came flying toward her through the hatch in the bar area. Startled, the manager approached the players at the pool table, jokingly admonishing them to keep their balls on the table. But all of their balls were accounted for; it was a spare. To add to the enigma, no one was near the bar area at the time who could have thrown it.

On another day, several staff and patrons witnessed a two-liter bottle of vodka fall from the wine rack and shatter on the ground. SPI UK investigators argue that the sheer number and variety of bizarre occurrences reported at the Inn make it difficult to simply dismiss them as coincidences or explain them away with skepticism. They vow to return again, armed with more high-tech tools and unflinching determination.

If there is a passage linking the living and the deceased, these apparition chasers believe they have the patience—and the technology—to uncover it. In their world, the world of the paranormal, every creak of time-worn wood, every shadow’s fleeting waltz slipping past the awareness of the casual observer might be a potential scientific breakthrough and a gateway to a story untold.

body.title: Dandadan Is Following the Most Annoying Modern Anime Trend
body.description: Dandadan is yet another hit anime property with critical acclaim leaving fans wanting more due to an irritating trend with ...
body.article_content:
Dandadan is already a smash hit. The new anime adaptation of Yukinobu Tatsu’s wild manga dominated Netflix’s streaming charts upon its release and has scored rave reviews from audiences and critics. Social media is overwhelmed by fans discussing the latest episodes, creating their own cosplay, or re-producing its now iconic opening credits. Dandadan is so wild and unpredictable that fans could easily binge 100 episodes and never get bored. But, unfortunately, we’re already over halfway through Season 1!

Videos by ComicBook.com

After having his testicles stolen by the yokai Turbo Granny, Okarun enlists the help of his new friend Momo to fight paranormal and extra-terrestrial forces and regain his privates. We’re all obsessed with Momo’s mission, and the blossoming romance between the two leading characters. So why does Season 1 have to end so soon? Dandadan’s first season will only run for a measly 12 episodes, as the show follows the most irritating trend in modern anime.

Studio Pierrot

Anime Used to Have 24-Episode (and Longer) Seasons

Have you ever scrolled through a streaming service like Crunchyroll or Netflix and discovered a classic immensely popular anime, only to discover that each season is well over 50 episodes long? It’s an overwhelming feeling every contemporary anime fan can relate to. If you’re eager to go back and watch One Piece or Dragonball Z, prepare for a long commitment. Ignoring their total episode counts, each Season (or arc) of One Piece is roughly 60-episodes long, while Dragonball Z isn’t even listed with seasons, as fans must chew their way through all 291 episodes without a natural breaking point.

Older shows had longer season runs for two key reasons. The first, and most controversial is the sheer number of filler and re-cap episodes. Of One Piece‘s 1122 episodes, 94 (8%) are considered to be pure filler by the fan base. Naruto is an even bigger culprit, as 90 of its 220 episodes are classed as filler — that’s 40%!

Older anime also tend to be longer because they were originally made for children. In Japan, shows produced for a younger audience didn’t have season breaks. This would explain Dragonball Z‘s overwhelmingly long 291-episode series.

Even lesser-known shows like the sports anime Hajime no Ippo, or the criminally underappreciated Monster ran for over 70 episodes. Should every single new anime follow this trend and deliver an overabundance of new episodes? The die-hard viewers among us will say yes. Although it’s an unrealistic expectation. After all, the animators have lives outside of work and families to get home to. But even 24-episode seasons are becoming less common.

Shows like Naruto, Attack on Titan, Jujutsu Kaisen, the first season of Demon Slayer, and Assassination Classroom are all keeping the trend of 24+ episode seasons alive. After all, if we’re waiting for over a year and half for a new season, it’s incredibly disappointing when that wait is rewarded by just eight or ten episodes. So why have the episode counts of newer anime been drastically reduced?

MAPPA

Why Modern Anime Has Fewer Episodes

Hell’s Paradise (pictured above), Kaiju No. 8, the newer seasons of Demon Slayer, the aforementioned Dandadan, and Chainsaw Man are just a few new anime to have their seasonal episode counts slashed. Of course, there is no evil overlord selecting random anime to have fewer episodes. But there are a few reasons why new shows seem to be a lot shorter.

Firstly, and most prominently, producing anime is expensive. In the end, all things in entertainment come down to cost, and quality anime is increasingly expensive to produce. An issue of Shukan Toyo Keizai (via SK Anime) reported that a single episode of anime costs anywhere between $140,000-180,000. As a result, a 12-episode season costs an average of $1.9 million. And that’s just an estimate. As the quality of anime increases, audiences expectations increase, and the quality has to progress once more, which all results in further costs. Factor in Japan’s economy and inflation, and anime is an increasingly costly medium.

Secondly, studios favor short debut seasons to test the waters, and gauge audience interest in a new anime. The 2022 smash-hit, Chainsaw Man only ran for 12 episodes. However, after its tremendous success, a feature-length movie has officially been announced, and the franchise is expected to have a long future.

Finally, and perhaps most importantly, most modern anime are adaptations of popular manga. Every show mentioned above is an adaptation. As a result, the shows are limited by how much overall story there is to adapt. In the case of Demon Slayer, its short new seasons result from adapting shorter arcs from the manga.

Here’s hoping that Dandadan, and all the new shows listed above, get longer subsequent seasons in the future. As incredible as the shows are, 12-episode seasons don’t satisfy the craving felt by a lot of fans for more episodes from the newest, most promising shows.

body.title: Ratio.dev Presents New Book "AI Nocode Wizardry" Empowers Non-Programmers to Build AI Applications in 37 Days
body.description: November 27, 2024) - A groundbreaking book, AI Nocode Wizardry - How to Build a Powerful AI Application in 37 Days With Bubble.io, is set to revolutionize AI application development. The book provides ...
body.article_content:
Orlando, Florida--(Newsfile Corp. - November 27, 2024) - A groundbreaking book, AI Nocode Wizardry - How to Build a Powerful AI Application in 37 Days With Bubble.io, is set to revolutionize AI application development. The book provides a step-by-step guide for non-programmers to create sophisticated AI applications using no-code platforms, challenging traditional notions of AI development.

Dennis Lewis, the author and an expert in AI and no-code development, has created a comprehensive roadmap that allows business founders and entrepreneurs to transform their ideas into fully functional AI applications in just 37 days. This innovative approach combines the power of Bubble.io, a leading no-code platform, with cutting-edge AI tools to democratize AI development.

AI Nocode Wizardry addresses the growing demand for AI solutions while breaking down the barriers that have traditionally kept non-programmers from entering the field. The book offers a unique perspective on rapid AI application development, providing readers with the tools and knowledge to create scalable, sustainable AI applications without writing a single line of code.

AI Nocode Wizardry

To view an enhanced version of this graphic, please visit:

https://images.newsfilecorp.com/files/10373/231585_8c5fbecd74966892_001full.jpg

Lewis states: "There are so many people with real-world experience and great ideas for how to harness AI and solve business problems, but they lack the technical skills to make it happen. This book is about avoiding those traps and getting to market fast in a way that allows your business to adapt and grow."

Key features of the book include:

A 37-day plan for developing AI applications from concept to launch

Detailed instructions on integrating multiple AI models with Bubble.io

Strategies for creating scalable and sustainable applications

Real-world examples and case studies of AI-powered tools built with no-code platforms

Insights on the future of work and the changing landscape of AI development

The book challenges the conventional wisdom that sophisticated AI applications require extensive coding skills and significant time investment. By leveraging no-code platforms and AI tools, AI Nocode Wizardry presents a revolutionary approach that can accelerate innovation cycles and democratize AI development across various industries.

"We're on the cusp of a true revolution in democratizing AI app development," the author explains. "By combining Bubble and leading AI tools, we're going to see amazing things come out onto the market in a very short time."

The release of AI Nocode Wizardry comes at a time when businesses are increasingly looking to incorporate AI into their operations to improve efficiency and customer service. The book provides a timely solution for entrepreneurs and professionals who have been hesitant to explore AI due to perceived technical barriers.

The author advises:

"Don't squander your limited resources on traditional software development. Start with a solid framework, utilize great technologies like Bubble and the AI tools showcased in the book, and leverage experienced companies like Ratio.dev to get over the initial hurdles quickly."

AI Nocode Wizardry not only provides practical guidance but also addresses concerns about the scalability and long-term viability of applications built using no-code platforms. The book details how to construct a solid architecture for sustainable and scalable applications that can support hundreds of thousands or even millions of users.

As the field of AI continues to evolve, AI Nocode Wizardry prepares readers for future advancements by emphasizing the importance of understanding customer needs and leveraging technology to solve specific problems. Lewis believes that the true value in the future will lie in the ability to apply AI tools effectively to address real-world challenges.

"This is just the beginning of a new age of powerful business management systems and online systems for customers," the author concludes. "We're just beginning to see the tip of the iceberg in terms of how AI can be integrated into all sorts of business processes."

AI Nocode Wizardry - How to Build a Powerful AI Application in 37 Days With Bubble.io is now available for purchase. For more information or to request a review copy, please contact Dennis Lewis, hello@ratio.dev.

About the Author:

Dennis Lewis, a tech veteran with 35 years of experience, is revolutionizing AI development through no-code platforms. A certified Bubble developer and AI enthusiast, Dennis has transitioned from complex coding to creating powerful AI applications with drag-and-drop simplicity. His book, AI Nocode Wizardry, aims to democratize AI development, empowering innovators regardless of coding skills. When not mentoring startups or building AI-powered applications, Dennis enjoys experimenting with online tools, perfecting his lasagna recipe, and walking his pitbull. Join Dennis in reshaping the tech landscape, one no-code AI project at a time.

About Ratio.dev:

Ratio.dev, launched in 2009, provides specialized no-code application development, improvement, and optimization services using the Bubble platform. With particular expertise around blockchain, AI, and web3 integrations, the certified boutique agency focuses on providing fixed-cost, high-ROI solutions that speed ideas to market. Ratio.dev is based in Orlando, Florida. More information can be found on their no-code development blog.

To view the source version of this press release, please visit https://www.newsfilecorp.com/release/231585

body.title: A Guide to Establishing a Tech Startup in Dubai’s Thriving Ecosystem
body.description: Establishing a tech startup involves careful planning and execution, especially in a dynamic city like Dubai. Known for its ...
body.article_content:
Establishing a tech startup involves careful planning and execution, especially in a dynamic city like Dubai. Known for its robust economic environment and strategic location, Dubai has become a global hub for technology and innovation. The influx of international venture capitalists and a supportive government framework make it an attractive destination for entrepreneurs. This guide walks you through essential aspects of launching your tech startup in Dubai, emphasizing the steps to navigate its promising ecosystem successfully.

Understanding Dubai’s Business Environment

Rapid growth, diverse industries, and substantial investment opportunities characterize Dubai’s business environment. The UAE government offers numerous startup incentives, including tax exemptions and streamlined registration processes. Its policies foster innovation and make it easier for entrepreneurs to launch new businesses. Companies operating in free zones enjoy complete ownership and benefits such as relaxed regulations.

Additionally, industry-specific free zones enable startups to tap into niche markets, enhancing their competitive edge. Conducting thorough market research is crucial to understanding the local landscape. This knowledge allows you to identify gaps and opportunities in the market, guiding your business strategy. When setting up a business in Dubai, engaging with local business consultants significantly assists in navigating regulatory obligations and logistical challenges. Their expertise can streamline your entry into the market and provide insights into local consumer behavior. Overall, understanding the business environment in Dubai is foundational to establishing a successful startup.

Creating a Solid Business Plan

A well-structured business plan acts as a roadmap for your startup’s growth. This document defines your business objectives, target market, financial forecasts, and marketing strategies. Begin by clearly outlining your product or service and what differentiates it from competitors. An effective business plan should also highlight your unique value proposition, effectively addressing customer pain points. Financial projections play a vital role in attracting investors and securing funding. Detail your anticipated expenses, revenue models, and break-even analysis to present a compelling case.

Complying with Legal Requirements

Complying with Dubai’s legal requirements is a critical step toward a successful startup launch. Securing the necessary licenses and permits depends on your business type and the industry in which you operate. The Dubai Department of Economic Development (DED) plays a crucial role by issuing essential licenses to local and foreign enterprises. The types of permits include commercial, industrial, and professional categories, each requiring specific approvals. Alongside business registration, understanding local labor laws and regulations is vital for managing employees effectively. Dubai’s employment laws govern contracts, wages, and worker rights, ensuring you adhere to the legal framework.

Building a Network and Community

Establishing a solid professional network is essential for any startup. Dubai hosts various tech events, expos, and networking platforms, presenting numerous opportunities to connect with industry leaders and potential investors. Participating in these events allows you to showcase your startup, gain feedback, and forge valuable relationships. Collaborating with fellow entrepreneurs can lead to mentorship opportunities and even partnerships that strengthen your business. Moreover, exploring online platforms such as LinkedIn can expand your reach beyond physical events. Engaging with groups focused on technology and startups allows you to share ideas and trends while learning from peers. Overall, networking creates a robust ecosystem vital for startup success in Dubai.

Securing Funding for Your Startup

Funding is often one of the most significant hurdles for entrepreneurs. Fortunately, Dubai’s vibrant startup ecosystem features various funding sources, including angel investors, venture capital firms, and government grants. Exploring these avenues lets you find the proper financial support that aligns with your business vision. Local banks and financial institutions also offer loan programs tailored to startups, making it easier to access capital. Participating in business competitions and startup accelerators can provide funding, mentorship, and exposure. These platforms often offer seed funding in exchange for equity, allowing you to validate your business model under expert guidance. Proactively seeking funding sources will play a significant role in your startup’s sustainability.

Leveraging Technology in Your Startup

In today’s fast-evolving landscape, leveraging technology can give your startup a competitive advantage. It can enhance efficiency, streamline processes, and facilitate scalability. Start by integrating cutting-edge tools and software that align with your operational needs, such as project management, customer relationship management (CRM), and data analytics tools. Furthermore, focusing on digital marketing strategies is essential for reaching a broader audience. Social media, email marketing, and SEO will elevate your online brand presence. Enhancing security protocols and data protection measures safeguards customer information and fosters trust. Regular training sessions for personnel on technology updates are also crucial, ensuring that your team remains proficient with the tools available. By prioritizing technology, your startup will be better positioned to adapt and grow in the competitive market.

Making informed decisions is essential to aligning your business with evolving customer needs, and embracing a mindset of improvement positions your startup for long-term viability and success. Establishing a tech startup in Dubai requires a blend of strategic planning, compliance, and community building. Each step is crucial in ensuring your business is well-positioned for growth in this thriving ecosystem. By understanding the local landscape, creating solid plans, complying with legal requirements, and fostering relationships, you set your startup on a path toward success.

body.title: Patient Registry Software Market Trends, Innovations, and Forecast Analysis 2024-2032
body.description: The global patient registry software market size was US$ 1191.1 million in 2021. The global patient registry software market to surpass US$ 2.9 billion by 2030 by registering a compound annual growth ...
body.article_content:
Report Ocean has published a new report on the Patient Registry Software Market, delivering an extensive analysis of key factors such as market restraints, drivers, and opportunities. The report offers a detailed examination of industry trends and developments shaping the growth of the Patient Registry Software market. It also provides a comprehensive analysis and forecast of the market future performance.

The global patient registry software market size was US$ 1191.1 million in 2021. The global patient registry software market to surpass US$ 2.9 billion by 2030 by registering a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 11.7% throughout the forecast period, i.e., 2022-30.

Request To Download Free Sample of This Strategic Report @https://reportocean.com/industry-verticals/sample-request?report_id=Pol1261

Patient registration software (PRS) is a computerized database installed in healthcare centers. The system contains personal, medical, social, and financial information. Registries may offer academics and medical professionals’ crucial epidemiological information about common and uncommon diseases, including incidence and prevalence, symptoms, and severity.

Factors Influencing the Market



The growing adoption of Electronic Health Records to save patients’ data and use it at any time and any moment will primarily drive the growth of the patient registry software market. The healthcare sector is evolving at a steep rate throughout the globe, owing to the growing prevalence of diseases and rising private and government spending in this sector. Apart from that, authorities are also focusing on adopting advanced technology, which is attributed to fuel the growth prospects of the market during the study period.



Efforts to improve patient care services increases patient involvement, and trending concept of telemedicine is expected to bring untapped growth opportunities to the market during the study period.



However, privacy and data security concerns may limit the market growth during the analysis period.

COVID-19 Impact Analysis



Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the adoption of Electronic Health Records increased. The pandemic raised the burden on the healthcare sector due to the large patient pool. Various countries witnessed a drastic drop in the availability of hospital beds and services. To provide efficient services even at a time of staff shortage, the demand for patient registry software increased substantially.

Get a Free Sample PDF copy of the report @https://reportocean.com/industry-verticals/sample-request?report_id=Pol1261

Regional Analysis



North America is expected to dominate the patient registry software market during the study period. An expanding target population, rising illness prevalence, and the demand for population-based registries all contribute to the market’s expansion in this region. Additionally, this area is a significant contributor to the patient registry software market due to expanding government activities. To make patient registry software for clinical research more interactive and user-friendly, businesses are always working to develop user-interactive software. The Asia Pacific region is expected to record lucrative growth during the projection period. The use of electronic medical records has grown during the last few years. The growing aging population, frequent hospital visits, elevated diagnostic errors, and growing demand to reduce medical errors are the main market drivers in the region.
